results.description:
We'll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery for a run on the Old Croton Aqueduct. Afterward, whoever is interested can head to the Red Barn Bakery for breakfast. This is a good run for new runners because it is out and back - no set distance to cover but you will need to wear a watch. Feel free to turnaround at any point or walk/run at your own pace. 

Details about the Saturday run

Route: We’ll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St.) in Irvington and jog VERY casually together to the Old Croton Aqueduct trail. From there we’ll head south toward Dobbs Ferry. There is no set distance. Everyone will walk or run at their own pace for 25 minutes, and then turn around and come back. Please wear a watch so that you know when to turn around.

Note to newcomers: If you are unfamiliar with the area and would prefer to walk rather than run to the trail, click here to see the trail on a map.


Water/Bag Storage: There are very few water fountains along the route, so bring a water bottle if you need one while running. I’ll bring water and cups for after the run. There’s no bag storage, so leave belongings at home or in your car.

Location: In front of Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St, Irvington, NY 10533). Free parking is available on weekends in the MetroNorth lot next door.

</a> <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/1452433901730637/">Join our Facebook group to post pictures or message other members.

General advice & guidelines for our regular meetup runs:

• RSVP if you are going. If your plans change, simply change your RSVP.

• There is no bag storage, so please bring only what you plan to run with.

• All regular runs are rain or shine, unless the weather is actually dangerous.

• If you arrive late, can’t find the start location, miss us for any reason, run anyway!

• If you missed RSVP deadline, and know our starting point, feel free to join us on the day – just this one time :)

Feel free to contact me either via my meetup account or at [masked] if you have any questions.

results.description:
Breakneck is a great scramble with great views all the way up. From the top of breakneck we can do sugarloaf or the undercliff trail back to the parking lot. 

If it your first time you'll probably want to follow the trail up breakneck, but there are spicier routes for people with climbing experience.

-Andre


--------------------------


The Basics:

This is not a hike for beginners.  We generally try to stay together, but we do have a schedule to keep and can't wait for slower hikers. 

Terrain: Steep scrambling and several hills


Elevation Gain: 1500+ feet

Distance: ~5 miles

Meeting Location:
Link to the trailhead/trailend parking lot:parking lot (that's[masked], [masked] in case the link doesn't work. Just go to Google maps and enter the coordinates). This is the larger parking lot about 0.2mi north of the tunnel.

Public Transportation Meeting Location & Return Time:
Metro North Railroad: Take the 7:43am train from Grand Central to the Breakneck Ridge stop, arriving at 9:07am. 

<google maps link>

Trains leave Cold Spring station hourly.  It is a  ~1.5 mile road walk from where we will finish and there's usually some drivers willing to shuttle people to the station.

Car Drivers and Riders:
People who are coming by car and are willing to give rides, please write in your RSVP from where and when you are leaving. If you'd like a ride, please contact a driver (and bring $5 to chip in for gas and tolls.)

Day Hiking Gear:
 Standard fall gear: hiking boots, non-cotton clothes.

It is always a little cooler and windier on the hills, so bring one more warm layers then you expect to need, a windbreaker, a warm hat.

2 liters of water minimum, 3 liters suggested

Lunch, snacks and extra food.

East Hudson Trails hiking map

Headlamp (just in case)

Rain Gear (just in case)

Sunscreen, sunglasses


Hiking poles are nice


East Hudson Trail Map (Amazon.com store.)

Weather:
Check the forecast for Cold Spring, New York.
results.name: Breakneck Ridge Scramble [Public Transit Accessible]

results.description:
Saturday, September 12th, 25k (15.5) miles on the infamous Greenbelt Trail!

Trail Details: Run from Plainview, Long island to Cold Spring Harbor and back 7.75 miles each way. This trail varies from mild flats to technical hills and roots. Just because this is Long Island, don't assume that this trail is flat. As always, we encourage all speeds to join, no matter how fast or slow. This is about running trails and having fun! If you can’t run 15 miles and can only run 7, no worries! This trail is an "up and back", so you can just turn around.

Where: Meet at the HIcksville LIRR Train Station.

When: 9:10 am

Via public transit: Take the 8:22 am Long Island Rail Road from Penn Station to Hicksville. Travel time 48 minutes. (Alternatively, you can take the LIRR from any station as long as you arrive on the 9:10 train.) There is a 5 mile cab ride to the trail head. Cost per car $8.

If you are driving: The Hicksville Station is located on the corner of Newbridge Road & West Barclay Street in Hicksville
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be standing outside wearing BTR t-shirts and looking like trail runners.
results.name: Weekend Trail Run! #1

Just bring a No. 2 Pencil and all other materials will be prepared for you. Make sure to RSVP because if we run out of room, you'll be taking the test standing. If you have any questions, feel free to comment, message me, or email me at [masked]. 

Hope to see you there!

venue.name: Stanley Isaacs Senior Center

results.description:
This volunteer opportunity helps a segment of the NYC population that is particularly vulnerable (our home-bound seniors) and is facing a steadily growing problem - hunger. As our city’s elderly grow older, they are more likely to have mobility limitations, while living at or below the poverty level. The elderly of East Harlem are particularly more vulnerable, residing in challenging living conditions alone, and who can no longer shop or cook for themselves.

Citymeals-on-Wheels (www.citymeals.org) raises private funds to ensure no homebound elderly New Yorker will ever go a day without food or human company. Citymeals funds 33 community-based agencies that bring weekend, holiday and emergency meals to homebound elderly New Yorkers - one of the agencies we'll be helping as volunteers.

How are we helping?

On Saturday, September 12th, we'll assist the Stanley Isaacs Senior Center Citymeals-on-Wheels program with delivery of meals to the elderly. Volunteers should wear weather appropriate clothes and comfortable shoes as deliveries are done on foot within walking distance from the meal center.  Although the weather may not always be favorable, the meals MUST be delivered as many, if not all, of the elderly in the program RELY on the meal delivery for the day.

Our Meetup

We'll meet at the Senior Center at 9:30am on Saturday for a short training, then break into small teams of 3 to 4 people to deliver the meals to the elderly.

If you RSVP, please try to be on time, or arrive no later than 9:30am, which is when we start delivery. The time commitment ends at 12pm and goes by very quickly. 

If you have any questions, running late, need more information on parking and etc., feel free to call/text Daniel at 774.275.3646.

Directions to the Union Settlement Senior Center

The Stanley Isaacs Senior Center is located at 415 East 93rd Street. The closest subway is the #6 train to 96th Street & Lexington Avenue, then walking east to 93rd street & 1st Avenue. The building is offset from the street (toward the FDR Drive), enter through sliding glass doors. The M15 bus line stops nearby, along 1st Ave.

Thanks and see you there!
results.how_to_find_us: Inside the Senior Center
results.name: Volunteer Opportunity! Citymeals on Wheels Food Delivery For The Elderly

results.description:
Are you Looking to get fit?

Need to drop a few pounds?

Want to get in shape for the summer?

Try a FREE Boot Camp class at CrossFit Outbreak in Ft. Greene Park.


Our Boot Camp classes are designed to introduce you to CrossFit. We want to get you fit and healthy, challenge your mind and  body - we love to  MAKE FITNESS FUN.


The first class is free, each class after that is $15.00.


There is no obligation to join our gym outside of this class. 


The Exercises: CrossFit is a combination of strength, cardio, muscle endurance, flexibility, core, and functional movement patterns. You get EVERYTHING you need!


Time Efficient Training. Our classes are 60 minutes in length. We utilize the principle of muscle confusion. You will NEVER do the same workout twice! Why is this good? Because…your body will never adapt and you will keep on getting stronger and fitter.


Make sure to click on the link below to register for the class and sign our waiver form --->

results.description:
Back by popular demand, we will head out of the city to Pearl River, NY for some yarn shopping and beer drinking!  It is the Deviant Brewery for 10 year anniversary party!   And The Stichery will have a special Pints 'n' Purls discount and extra close-out deals since we are taking our third annual trip up there.  (Usually, the 10% off is only for their mid-summer sale in the end of July.)


The 10:07 train from Penn Station gets to Pearl River at 11:11.  (We have to transfer at Seacus.)  Please be at Penn Station no later than 10:00.  We will head to the train at that time.  The next train in about an hour later.  Try to arrive by 9:45.  Get some Krispy Kreme and a coffee and buy your ticket. 

More about the brewery and anniversary party: http://heyevent.com/event/fwlmvtk4sanh4a/defiant-brewing-co-10th-anniversary-party

More about The Stichery: http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-stitchery-pearl-river  http://www.thestitcheryny.com/

Bring your growlers to fill them up super cheap at the Defiant Brewing Company.  It's across the street from the train station, so you can fill up and head back without having to carry it far.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet outside the New Jersey Transit booths by the escalator into Penn Station
results.name: Trip to the Defiant Brewery and shopping at The Stichery

results.description:
Ok everyone ,

This  month we are taking advantage of the many guided tours around our history filled area  & giving my  voice a rest ... last week we went in the aqueduct tunnel  so this weekend we will walk along a portion of the tunnel above ground and marvel at the impressive mansions that line this amazing feature .. we will meet in front of the Irvington town hall   which has a beautiful reading room  thats stunning all on its own  if were lucky we will be able to grab a peek inside , the aqueduct trail is dirt with some rocks  proper  closed foot wear is a must .  bring some water .we will pass along the madam C.J  Walkers   BEAUTIFUL HOME   , and enter the lynhurst property  this is a historical guided tour starting 'their time" so please  be on time  THEY WILL NOT WAIT FOR US  THIS TOUR IS appx 2.5 hr ROUNDTRIP  to see millionaires mansions and learn some amazing things   THEY CAN SOMETIMES BE CONVINCED TO DO A SHORT  TRIP IN THE SOULTHY DIRECTION IF ENOUGH PEOPLE STILL WANT TO CONTINUE .. ALSO PLEASE BRING A $1 OR $2 TO TIP THE GUIDE .

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Come join us for some challenging Rock Scrambling and Crevice Exploration at Mohonk Preserve and put your Rock Scrambling skills to the test! Though the mileage is short, this is no average walk in the park!  You will get a full body workout while exploring the many crevices, towering rock walls and breakdown of the "Lost City" and Bonticou Crag.


1) OUR FIRST STOP WILL BE THE "LOST CITY"

WE WILL MEET AT THE COXING TRAILHEAD @ MOHONK PRESERVE

807 Clove Rd

Gardiner, NY

[masked], [masked]


http://www.mohonkpreserve.org/coxing-trailhead

Our adventure at Lost City: The trail in to Lost City is approx 1 mile.  The majority of our time will be spent at the cliff base in the scrambles and climbs of the "Lost City". With the East facing cliffs we will take advantage of the morning sun. There are also some small dark crevices to explore for the more adventurous so be sure to bring a headlamp!


2) OUR SECOND STOP WILL BE AT BONTICOU CRAG

WE WILL RELOCATE TO THE SPRINGFARM TRAILHEAD @ MOHONK PRESERVE

Upper 27 Knolls Rd

High Falls, NY 12440

[masked], [masked]

http://www.mohonkpreserve.org/spring-farm-trailhead

Our adventure at Bonticou Crag: Bonticou is like a giant playground of scrambles and climbs surrounded by beautiful views of the adjacent Catskills.  Bonticou also offers some small Talus caves beneath its breakdown for the more adventurous! (You might consider bringing some knee-pads, a helmet and a headlamp if you want to explore these.)  If you've ever been to Bonticou before you probably only touched the surface.  We will fully explore the area taking "trails" up and down the cliff face on the left, right and middle as well as scrambling through its breakdown for the entire length of the outcropping.



TOTAL DISTANCE: Approximately 6 miles

SCRAMBLING PACE: Slow but physically challenging (not to be confused with easy)

ESTIMATED HIKE/SCRAMBLE TIME: 6-7 hours

DIFFICULTY: Advanced Beginner / Intermediate - Rocky Terrain & Crevices with possible loose, slippery or jagged rocks. Must have a good sense of balance and not have an unnatural fear of heights

CURRENT WEATHER FORECAST: Cloudy with a high of 72 degrees.

FEE: Please Note Mohonk Preserve charges a $12. fee for day use.  Season Passes are also available for $55. or $45. for students.  If you enjoy Mohonk preserve you can apply your $12. day usage fee towards the purchase of a membership by simply saving and submitting your bracelet (pass) within 2 weeks of purchase at the Visitor Center.


RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Climbing Helmet (Bicycle helmet will do) Not mandatory but rocks could get kicked loose (especially recommended if you want to check out the Talus caves at Bonticou)

• Raincoat/Windbreaker or long sleeve shirt for cave

• Sunscreen, Bug Spray/Tick Repellant

• "Scrambling" Gloves - Lightweight with good grip - Gardening gloves from Home Depot work great!

• Shoes with good grip - preferably with ankle support

• Headlamp with spare batteries - Home Depot has a great 100 lumen headlamp for only $12.99!

• A Small Pack - nothing too large that will become a hindrance in the scrambles

• Related maps, a Compass or GPS, Water, Snacks, First Aid, etc.


RELATED MAPS:

New York - New Jersey Trail Conference - Shawangunk Trails Map Set


**HEAVY RAIN WILL CANCEL THIS EVENT**


NYC HIKING & OUTDOOR ADVENTURE GROUP LEGAL DISCLAIMER
Waiver of liability

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.


If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.


The NYC Hiking & Outdoor Adventure Group does not provide liability insurance for the protection of individuals who may participate in any of the events planned by the Organizer or Assistant Organizers.


This release extends and applies to, and also covers and includes, all unknown, unforeseen, unanticipated and unsuspected injuries, damages, loss and liability.


Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. By signing up for this group or event you understand that you are attending all events AT YOUR OWN RISK. Organizers and Assistant Organizers of this group are just that, we organize the events and hike together as friends. There are no leaders on these hikes, you are your own leader- This is YOUR hike.
results.name: SCRAMBLICIOUS Double Feature! LOST CITY & BONTICOU CRAG @ Mohonk Preserve

results.description:
Here's Our Schedule: (Times are approximate.) 

10:00 - Welcome 

10:15 - Show & Tell - We show things we've made since the last meeting or before and ask for help with any problems we might have encountered.

11:15-11:30 - Break for refreshments.

11:30  - Demo begins

1:00 - Meeting usually ends

$3.00 fee goes toward the cost of listing the meetings on this Meetup site.

Supply List - (The week of August 23 - 29th, Michaels has the beads on sale for 40% off, basic findings $2.53 and if you have a coupon, you can use if for the wire.)

 26 gauge wire (Approximately 24 feet)

47- 8mm beads

results.description:
LEADER: Louise Parnell ([masked] or[masked] (c)[masked])

RATING: C 3 C

Meet at 10AM in the parking lot behind Confetti restaurant on Ash St. in Piermont. Richard Esnard of the Piermont Historical Society will walk with us and discuss the history of Piermont, the pier and Bogertown. TCmap 109

*   *   *   *   *   *

Our full hike schedule can be viewed on our website at hudsonhikers.org, and some hikes are also posted on our Facebook page.

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities.  Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance. 

Pace Ratings: 
     A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster 
     B = Moderate - about 2 mph 
     C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less 

Distance:Noted in miles 

Terrain Ratings:
     A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents, 
             possible rock scrambling
     B = Moderate climbs and descents
     C = Generally flat with little elevation change 

For example, a hike rated “B 7 A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling. 

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike. 

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

NO SHOW/LATE CANCELLATION POLICY:
Please be considerate of event hosts/organizers and others who may want to attend an event by not being a "NO SHOW" (failing to show up when you've RSVP'd "yes") or a "LATE CANCEL" (changing RSVP to a "no" within 24 hours of an event).  If you have a history of No Shows and/or Late Cancels, we may have to bump you to the waiting list for meetups with limited space, in favor of those with a positive attendance history.

JUST IN CASE YOU CAN'T FIND ANYONE OR DON'T KNOW YOUR WAY AROUND, YOU CAN ALWAYS LOOK FOR ME!

Hi Everyone! I'm doing this event again and I would like to set up with those that are interested. We're going to crawl around different vendors to eat varies food. This event is mainly to explore the variety of food vendors so you are all welcome to join me and stay for the shows afterward.

This event is free and no organizer fee will be charge.  Just come out and enjoy the day. This is the event program and if you wish to go there early and explore by yourself, catch some of their shows, you are free to do so. 

This event will be on 6th Ave Between Houston St. and Bleecker St. 

Meeting Area: We will meet at the corner of 6th Ave and Houston St. where the benches are. 

------------------------------------------------------------------------

ABOUT the Event

With a wide range of Japanese food, arts, crafts, services, and performance, there is plenty to do and see for everyone!

Bring your family and friends and explore this extraordinary cultural event all day long. We are sure you will have a GREAT time with a lot of fun and excitement at the Japan Block Fair!

FOOD
The wide range of Japanese food is one fun part of the fair. From authentic noodles and curry to neo-Japanese cuisine and delicious sweets,we offer a large selection of delicious and healthy Japanese food at reasonable prices!

PRODUCTS
Just stroll around and take your time to browse through a variety of Japanese merchandise, arts, crafts, and more. Hard-to-find handmade jewelry and traditional Japanese wraps are some of the items showcased — enjoy the treasure hunt of a lifetime!

http://youtu.be/C2QDLymMsg8

PERFORMANCE
Come join us for an energetic stage live performance! Japanese cosplay (costume play) performances, traditional dance, Japanese rock band, Drums, samurai performances… there is something for everyone. Best of all — it’s all FREE!

http://youtu.be/4XWPfP8JdpE

We will start exploring at 10:15.

* If you arrive late or going to be late, just text me.

http://www.ThriveInThePark.com

Thrive in the Park was created by a group of friends with a common interest in fitness, clean food, and having a great time.

Our goal is to get in the best shape while in the company of great people.

Workout Details:

Bring a water bottle and your determination.

Our free workouts are created by certified fitness experts and are designed for everyone at any level of fitness. 


The work out will consist of body weight exercises (pushup, sit ups, squats, lunges, jumps, team competitions, partner exercises, etc).

If you have any questions, please send us a message and we'll get back to you.

Note: When you RSVP we will send you a telephone number you can call/text in case you have any trouble finding us.


What people are saying:

Achelle - #ThriveInThePark is the workout I look forward to all week! Not only do I get an incredible full body workout, but it's a fun and encouraging group to be apart of!

Devon - #ThriveInThePark is the best way to sweat out last night's wine.

History:

Thrive in the Park started in 2014. We believe in giving back to the community and in creating ripples of kindness, strength and gratitude. It is our hope that you too will go out into the world and create these ripples. 

We can't wait to see you!

results.description:
The F# community needs you!

The idea of “community code sprint” is to bring together active members of the community to a single place for a fun event where we can hack together on interesting projects, fix some of those long-standing bugs and feature requests, write amazing samples for talks, improve (or create!) documentation, and more.

We’ll have a room available for an entire day (so bring a charger ;-)), but we do not expect that everyone can spend the whole Saturday coding! So, feel free to come for half of a day.

Who should come and why? Come if you:

• contributed or created some F# open source project

• want to start contributing, but don’t know where to start

• want to do F# talks or write F# blogs, but need some feedback and help

What will we be working on? How to get ready?

To make the most from the day, you should come with some idea about what you want to do (or what projects are you interested in) and with a working machine where you can compile & run the project. If you’re not quite sure, then ask on Twitter (#fsharp), or at the F# open source mailing list, or take a look at the F# Foundation's list of projects and find a project that needs your help!

The exact topic very much depends on you, but the organizers can help you contribute or write a talk about nearly anything F#-related!

We look forward to improving the community with you!

P.S. - Here's a blog post by Rachel Reese about Nashville's recent code sprint.
results.name: Community Code Sprint!

Wanted storytellers, game designers, hackers, makers and fans of Sherlock Holmes. Come collaborate and help us design the experience that will unfold at Lincoln Center during the New York Film Festival on September 26th & 27th.

We're entering a very creative moment in the process. Together we'll shape an immersive experience that transform Lincoln Center's campus into a massive crime scene. 

This day long session on September 12th will build upon our successful meetup on August 15th (click to see the archive). The focus of the meetup will be on experience design, story creation, game asset generation and connected objects design and build. If you've touch into any of our 10 months of prototyping now is the time to return.  

Space is limited for this one. So make sure to RSVP early. 

Currently over 1000 people are collaborating around Sherlock Holmes & the Internet of Things from 60+ countries. Meetups are being staged in 25 cities around the globe. Become part of a global storytelling project. 

For more info visit 

http://sherlockholmes.io

http://www.indiewire.com/article/sherlock-holmes-the-internet-of-things-how-to-join-a-massive-storytelling-experiment-20150814


Sherlock Holmes & the Internet of Things is a prototype of the Columbia Digital Storytelling Lab in partnership with The New York Film Festival, the Made in NY Media Center by IFP, the Brown Institute of Media Innovation, the Columbia University School of the Arts and the Columbia School of Continuing Education.

results.description:
Provide Clothing to Children in Need: Help sort and pack back-to-school clothing!


We need volunteers to help us organize donated clothing. Volunteers will sort clothing for quality, size, gender and season and help create outfits and packages of clothing for children so we can fill pending orders. We receive on-going donations of clothing and need volunteers to help process these donations. 

* Children younger than 14 must be accompanied by an adult.  The minimum age to volunteer for this event is 11*  Please add +1's to your RSVP if you are bringing kids!

About The Sharing Shelf @ Family Services of Westchester:

The Sharing Shelf collects new and gently used clothing for children and youth as well as other basic necessities such as new school supplies, shoes, strollers, car seats and pack-n-plays. 12.9% of Westchester children live in poverty.  Fortunately The Sharing Shelf of FSW is able to meet their needs with the help of volunteers, donors and community clothing drives. Clothing is sorted by quality, size, season and gender, packaged in a week’s worth of clothing, then distributed though social service agencies to children and youth in need at no cost to the children or their families. The Sharing Shelf was founded by volunteers and is run entirely by volunteers. We rely on volunteers to achieve our mission.

More info here: Family Services of Westchester (FSW) http://www.fsw.org
results.name: Sort & Pack back-to-school clothing for children in need (kids 11+ welcome)

results.description:
Join us on Saturday, September 12, 2015 at 10:00 a.m. to hear Thomas Adair Rossman speak on the topic of the American Innovation Party (Curb Your Dogmatism), which was recently incorporated in New York State and seeks to run its candidates for elective office starting next year. The event will take place in the Library of the Queens Pride House located at[masked]th Avenue, Suite 206, Jackson Heights, New York 11372.

This is the official launch of the American Innovation Party and the first public speech of Thomas Adair Rossman, the Founder of the Party, since it was incorporated last month. You will experience the enthusiasm of a new movement and hear his detailed plan to be competitive with the two major parties. Rossman promises his presentation will be the most profound and engaging conversation you will ever have on how we can effect real improvement in the way we govern ourselves.     

Mr. Rossman has criticized the Libertarian Party and its supporters for doing the same old thing over and over again with the same results. Come and hear this brilliant strategist unveil his plan to make a difference in the political arena and see whether he has anything to offer that might be relevant to better-promoting freedom in this state and nation. Does he have a new plan or is he just another flash in the pan?

ADMISSION FEE: $3.00 for Queens LP members; $5.00 for Non-Members. 


If you are driving, arrive early to look for free street parking. There are also many 2-hour Muni-Meter spots and a nearby parking lot.

If you are coming by subway, use the IRT "7" Flushing Line and exit at 74th Street/Broadway. You can also use the IND "E", "F" or "R" Queens Blvd. Lines and exit at the Jackson Heights/Roosevelt Avenue stop.

If you get lost, call Dr. Tom Stevens on his cell phone at[masked]-7075.

================

Tom Rossman is an emerging global thought leader in improving political and economic decision making and has spent his career studying and investigating how people around the world can think and interact more effectively. As a young executive in finance during the 1990's, Rossman was an early champion of developing markets, investing in the newly emerging countries of Latin America and Asia far ahead of the crowd. Following Communism's collapse, Rossman took a key role at the leading Turkish Investment Bank, Global Securities, in bringing American capital and investment to the developing markets of the Former Soviet Union, Eastern Europe, Turkey and North Africa. By assisting in the privatization process within Eastern Europe and the Former Soviet Union, Rossman became an important link between Western capital and know-how in the early stages of modernizing these formally closed economic systems. First as an institutional advisor, and then as an independent consultant, he continued to advocate the sustainable development of democratic and stable free market institutions and expanding economic opportunity throughout the region. More recently, Rossman has provided a similar advisory role to major holding companies and financial institutions in the Middle East seeking to most effectively navigate through the volatility of the current financial crisis. 

Mr. Rossman has spoken on these topics at conferences around the world in such diverse places as London, New York, Istanbul, Baku, Almaty, Bishkek, Tashkent, Stockholm, Washington D.C. and Houston and he has lived in both Turkey and Kuwait. He studied religion and history at Nyack College in Nyack, New York and did his Master's work in international relations at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy in Medford, Massachusetts.

================

The reason why so many other fields of endeavor have experienced exponential advancement in the last 200 years , such as science, medicine, technology, etc…, while, at the same time,  we have achieved virtually no progress in political ideas and institutions,  is that those other fields adopted an overall worldview of continuous improvement and a method of reality-based analysis (how to determine what works and what doesn't), whereas in political and to a lesser extent,  economic thinking, we have allowed a worldview based on ideology, partisan division and special interests  to distort, divert and degrade intelligent, productive debate, ensuring that solutions are elusive.  The left-right polarization is based on a narrow, one-dimensional perspective of the world and both sides are at fault for the incompetence pervades our governments.  

This is what Modernity is all about --  Francis Bacon/the Scientific Revolution, John Locke, the Enlightenment, and the Founding Fathers were all striving towards- a society of continuously making life better for its citizens– which we now understand requires constant improvement through innovation, productivity and pluralism.  These foundational elements of Modern progress and prosperity are undermined by ideological illusion, partisan division and special interests. 

Transform your worldview and you can transform the world!!!!
results.name: Thomas Adair Rossman on American Innovation Party (Curb Your Dogmatism)

venue.name: Prospect Park Grassy Triangle, on drive, up from Grand Army Plaza entrance

results.description:
First walk of September! Bring your own ipod & earbuds. We dance walk around the park loop. What is dance walking? It's an improvised form of walking, with music, doing whatever movement comes naturally. It's walking and moving your arms. Or skipping, skitching, low-stepping, sideways running. It's responding to the rhythm, attitude, or story of the music you're hearing. In short, it's having a dance party in your living room, while walking through the park--hilarious and exhilarating. For inspiration, check out:

www.24hoursofhappy.com
results.how_to_find_us: Enter Prospect Park at Grand Army Plaza. Walk up drive 50 feet, meet on Grassy Triangle. You'll see me standing on the drive.
results.name: Dance Walk in Prospect Park--Saturday, September 12

results.description:
The Soho, Little Italy and Chinatown tour takes guests walking tour through the iconic streets of Soho with its cast iron buildings and upscale designer shops.  Little Italy will smell the authentic Italian cooking and famous mafia locations.  Chinatown offers colorful vendors and shows.

Date:  Sat. Sept. 12

Time:  10 a.m.

Price:  $35

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/soho-little-italy-and-chinatown-walking-tour-tickets-18347632262?aff=rjadventures


We will snack at the dumpling shop (cost of dumpling is $1 and this fee is not included in the tour)

Tour highlights include the experiences such as Soho’s Sites Cast Iron District, Haughwout Building, Heath Ledger’s Apartment building, Oldest Cheese Shop in NYC, Lombardi’s Pizza – NY’s first pizzeria, Mafia Hangouts, Canal and Motts Streets, Former Five Points District (Gangs of NY) Canal and Mott Street, Columbus Park, Old Opium Den, Ravenite Club – Mafia Hangout, Old NYC Police Headquarters, Sites of Men in Black Movie film, and Sici Tile Shop.
results.name: Soho, Little Italy and Chinatown Walking Tour

group.name: New York City Photo Walks - NYC Photo Walks

venue.address_1: 169 State Road - aka Rockaway Point Blvd.
venue.name: Fort Tilden Administration Building T-1

results.description:
This is an easy hike, over mostly level, sandy terrain.


We will meet at the Ft. Tilden Administration Building T-1 at 10:00.  From here we will cross Rockaway Point Blvd. and walk over to Riis Landing and then walk west along the shoreline on the bay side of the Rockaway Peninsula.  We will pass the beach community of Roxbury and then proceed along the beach past wild shoreline and an unusual glass beach.  


We continue along the bay past the beach community of Breezy Point and then on to the wild dunes and beaches of the Breezy Point Tip.  Along the way we keep our eyes open for various shore birds and possibly migrating hawks.  Most likely we will have the beach entirely to ourselves since we are now in one of the most inaccessible parts of Gateway National Recreation Area.  Amazingly, we are still in NYC.  From here we will walk out to the very tip of Breezy Point to the breakwater where on a clear day one can see all the way from Sandy Hook in NJ, the Verrazzano Bridge, Lower Manhattan, Coney Island and out over Jamaica Bay.  From here, we walk along the Atlantic Ocean beach and head east past Breezy Point summer cottages, beach clubs and the remains of Ft. Tilden.  We can stop to check out the view from atop an abandoned Nike missile silo.


Ft. Tilden is also a great place for birdwatching since it mostly undeveloped scrub forest.  Once we reach Ft. Tilden, we are back were we started.  The total walk is about 8 miles largely on sandy beaches.

If you are driving, free parking is available at the Riis Beach Parking Area.  Park at the extreme west end of the lot and then walk along Beach Channel Drive to the entrance to Ft. Tilden.  Turn left into the park and you will see the Administration Building in front of you to the left.  The walk from the parking lot is about half a mile.  Parking at Ft. Tilden is by permit only so you must park at Riis.

If you are coming via public transportation, take the 2 train to the end of the line - Flatbush Avenue stop.  Board the Q35 bus to Rockaway Park.  Ask the driver to let you off at Ft. Tilden/ Beach 169th St.  You can also take the A train to Broad Channel, transfer to S shuttle to Beach 116th St. and then take the Q22 or Q35 bus to Ft. Tilden.

Since most of this walk will be on sandy beaches, you will want to wear shoes that can get sandy and/or wet.  Hats, sunscreen and plenty of water are highly recommended. I also suggest you bring a lunch and/or snack although we will have an opportunity to stop at a deli in Breezy Point where sandwiches and beverages are available.


If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me (Joseph) directly at [masked] or call/text[masked]-2334.

Hike will go on rain or shine.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for Mark in his red Meetup T-shirt
results.name: Ft. Tilden/Breezy Point Hike

venue.name: littleBits Store:  A Lab For Creating Inventions Large and Small

results.description:
Go back to school in style with the coolest backpack out of all your friends! You’ll walk down the hallways with a book bag that can blink, buzz or even write out a message, but the best part is that you built it yourself.

At the littleBits Hack Your Backpack event, parents and guardians can gather with their kids to create their own wearable technology at the littleBits Store in New York City. This workshop is open to all kids ages 8+ and no prior hardware or programming experience is needed. Just bring your backpack and we will make it even better with Bits. Purchase of your hacked backpack is required. Your $10 admission will be taken off the final price of your hacked backpack. 

We will be hosting different stations during the event where you and your kid will learn how to design and create electronic wearable interfaces, compose your own music, and more! This is an event to encourage kids and their parents or guardians to create inventions together, so please only RSVP if you can attend with your kid. We anticipate this event selling out fast so get your ticket to secure your spot!

Check out some of our fun examples:
The Ultimate Backpack Alarm System (Approx. $90)
The Synth Backpack (Approx. $140)
LED Matrix Lightup (Approx. $115)

TO SIGNUP: http://www.eventbrite.com/e/hack-your-backpack-with-littlebits-tickets-18234176914
results.name: Hack your Backpack with littleBits

FREE Circuit Training Saturdays! A 50-minute non-stop intense workout. You will sweat off the weight, you will burn calories, you will gain muscle. All levels welcome. We vow to never give up on you. For we will do everything in our power to help you reach your goal. We operate in a judgement free zone to facilitate your comfort. We promise you will progress.

This Class consist of running, walking, floor exercise, abdominal  workouts, squats, jumprope, and much more. You always have the option to perform the modified version of any drill! This allows beginners or anyone with a minor injury to comfortable fit right in. Build your strength and endurance to perform the unmodified versions of the drill when you see FIT (pun intended :)!! All while moving to be beat of the music. Bring your family, bring your friends. 

Need further assistants locating us? Call[masked], someone will be happy to guide you! Note: We may not answer the phone during class hours!

results.description:
Pace easy, some hills. Distance 8 miles, duration 5 to 6 hours. After getting off the train at Exchange PlaceStation, we will walk south along the Hudson and then go inland to Paulus Hook and Historic Downtown Jersey City. We will then head north to Hoboken. Walk through Erie-Lackawanna Terminal, beautiful views of Manhattan westside, magnificent 100 year old buildings, Castle Point Terrace (Steven’s University), Sibly's Cave and the Hoboken Museum. Return to Manhattan via Hoboken Path Station 

Meeting: We will meet at Broadway and Vesey Street, across from St Paul’s Chapel (take the “E train to last stop or 1,2 or 3 train to Chambers Street and walk a few blocks south).The Path Train station is three blocks west on Vesey Street and the fare to New Jersey and back is $5.50.           

Leader: Tom McBreen (516)[masked](cell)

Contact hike leader directly if you have questions about the hike.

Free for paid annual Shorewalkers members, $3 for non-members, visit www.shorewalkers.org to join.

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

FALL (Sep - Nov)

As the city cools down we play four times a week. We use Riverside Park with Morningside Park as a backup.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!) 
- Tuesdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)

Damien

results.name: Saturday Ultimate @ 10AM - Riverside Park

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.

WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...

1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play elsewhere, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated

9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved

Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.


WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance

WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>
results.name: Tennis Social

results.description:
Student Testimonial:

"I have tried many different forms of meditation and yoga over the years. Though I have experienced some positive changes practicing over the years I never felt committed to practice on regular basis. Nan takes it to a whole other level. How and why? All I can say is you have to experience it for yourself. There is power in simplicity,love, and truth. Despite some language barriers(which are minor) You can feel her love and healing energy. Open your mind and see with a different set of eyes. I highly recommend her special Saturday classes." Michelina, Bodhi Meditation class Saturday November 15, 2014

“ My first time today. Nan is very helpful and dedicated. I enjoyed it immensely and I did experience a shift in energy. I feel more alert, relaxed and focused even as I write this testimony. I plan on attending her next class in Freeport." Michelina, Bodhi Meditation class September 17, 2014

“ Very strong healing energy tonight. I got there feeling very tired. I had stomach pain all day, and during the first meditation of the evening it got a lot better. By the end I wasn't thinking about it at all. I left full of energy. ” Pam, Bodhi Meditation class November 22, 2013

“ I didn't realize I would be reaping the benefits of Bodhi Med so quickly after attending only two classes. After my second class I felt even more relaxed. I have insomnia, but after the second session I fell asleep faster and deeper which has not happened for a long time. ” Dee, Bodhi Meditation class September 18, 2013

"I have been attending these classes for three weeks. They are amazing. Nan is wonderful! My energy level is shifting and I am beginning to experience an ongoing sense of well-being with balance and relaxation. Highly recommend!" Kathleen, Bodhi Meditation class October 25, 2013

------------------------------------------------------


Bodhi Meditation is a form of energy healing.


Bodhi Meditation is unique in the following ways


1). It channels universal energy rather than working with what’s within one person. It transcends the genetic and physical limits of just one being by relying and drawing energy from the entire universe.

2). The entire human body is the receiver of this energy. The energy’s effects on the body do not rely on certain meridian paths or pressure points of the body, which are the common requirements for many types of the Qi Gong practices.

Small group meditation sessions. Up to 7 people per meeting

I do Bodhi meditation, a form of energy healing.

If you open your heart and relax your mind you will benefit from this session. Benefit you physically and spiritually.

Seating, we have soft meditation mats and soft chairs whichever makes you feel more comfortable.

The session takes about 30-40 minutes followed by a discussion period. Tell me how you feel and what you felt.

Cost: $10

Regular meditation schedule:

Saturday: 10 - 11 AM

For travel from NYC:

Take the Long Island Railroad (Babylon branch) to Merrick

Location:

Ni Nan Healing Art Center

2326 Merrick Road

Merrick, NY 11566

Tel# [masked]

Have a great day,

Nan

 ---------------------------------------------------------------------

I leave you with Master JinBodhi's Golden Words:

(Editor's note: The following phrases were suggested by Master JinBodhi and subsequently introduced to his students as a daily practice. Starting your day by loudly reciting these phrases three times, either all of them or a select few, will bring you energy and joy. Give it a try and experience how uplifted you feel...)

1.Self-Confidence

I am most compassionate.

I am most confident.

I am most tolerant.

I am most courageous.

I keep my word.

I am most punctual.

I can do anything.

2. The Power of Knowledge

I am full of wisdom.

I am most knowledgeable.

I love reading.

I love observing.

I love listening.

I love thinking.

I take decisive action.

3. Life Purpose

 I am a gift from the Universe.

I am most charming.

I am most talented.

I can sing most beautifully.

I like challenge.

I am responsible for my actions.

I will fulfill my life purpose.

4. Cause and Consequence

（not for reading loud）

What you give is what you receive.

Care for others, and you are taken care of.

Smile at others, and they will smile at you.

Treat others with sincerity, and sincerity will be given to you.

Make trouble for others, and trouble will find you.

Frequent generosity begets abundance.

Seek to give, not to be rewarded.

results.description:
Early bird gets the brat and beer! ~10 miles RT. Start at Bear Mt Inn, hike or run to Oktoberfest and back! At Bear Mountain State Park. Exploratory adventure trek: Work together to use maps to route-find the shortest way. Get there quickly to beat the long lines! 

DETAILS

Meet at: 10:30 in front of Inn, (845)[masked] . Restrooms and water fountains inside by gift shop.


Transport: $26.70 RT public bus. Schedule and info. Depart NY Port Authority 8:45 AM. Return: Depart Bear Mt. 3PM and 5 PM. 

Cars: $8 /vehicle. If people want to drive to and volunteer as designated drivers (no drinking pls.), please say so in comments section below. We can carpool and split the cost of car admission and gas. If you do this, pls arrive early bec parking is nuts during this event.

Lunch: Everyone will run from start to meet at Oktoberfest for food and drink at Anthony Wayne Recreation Area! Starts at 12 PM. Pls leave Oktoberfest by 2PM to hike/run to catch 5 PM bus. Thank you to Jason for suggesting the event!

How:  Social. Partner / form pace groups. (Co-host Rosanna will run/walk as sweeper (combo: run slowly and fast hike). Feel free to go ahead at your own pace -- just make sure you have your running buddy, and  map as a guide!


Rain or shine. Heavy rain cancels! Check comments section for updates.

Who:  Trail runners and hikers. All paces are welcome!  Guests, friends and family are welcome. Each person is expected to be prepared, self-sufficient, able to find her way back to start, and able to help each other if necessary. Thanks.

Groups:  Each group/partner will wait for each other at intersections, leaving no one behind. This is a good opportunity to work as a team with other local hikers/runners at your level, test map-reading skills, and to discover trails without having to do it on your own.

REQUIREMENTS

BRING

1) Download/print and carry:  
a)  <a>Harriman Bear Mountain Trails</a> map (use #119) </a>(link) . 
b)  <a href="http://files.meetup.com/18274717/Bear_mt-AnthonyWayne_trail_map.jpg">Bear Mt-Anthony Wayne Rec. map**
c)  Find the shortest way to Oktoberfest, Anthony Wayne Rec area or use your map with suggested route:
Start at Bear Mt Inn -- 77E (red, through Doodletown) -- 77W (red) -- Fawn Trail -- Beechy Bottom Tr. ("bike trail") -- Anthony Wayne Rec area -- Return: Take same route (+ B (blue) trail on return for views!).  Total = ~10 miles.

2)  Backpack water and fuel! None on route!  

3)  Cash for Oktoberfest refreshments (check site for cc accepted)

*  Note: Pls leave Oktoberfest by 2PM to hike/run to catch 5 PM bus. Alt. option: We can take the way more challenging Bear Mt trail (yellow) route on return with plenty of climbs and views only if we have a driver (because of the duration, we may not make it in time for last bus). This would make total = approx. 15 mi.


**  Optional: You can buy the paper map at the gift shop. If closed, go to parks police station across the field. It's also available at REI. The purchase includes a whole set of area, however hard to read the tiny typeface. This is why I have incl. an image of part of the map for zooming in.


Facilities:  Restrooms and water fountains at start and at Oktoberfest (Anthony Wayne Rec area)

Weather:  Bear Mountain, NY

Comments? Want to form a carpool? Post in comments section below.

Happy trails!


_____________________________________________________


Note

This is not an organized training program. It is just a notice of activities some members are planning to do that is sent out to those who might want to join them. By choosing to join them, you agree that you are an adult over 21 and agree to the legal disclaimer. Each person is solely responsible for himself, and for following trail etiquette<a href="http://www.trailrunner.com/news/trail_etiquette.htm"></a>, laws, park rules, and park safety guidelines. Thanks!!!

"Picasso Sculpture" is a sweeping survey of Pablo Picasso’s innovative and influential work in three dimensions. This will be the first such museum exhibition in the United States in nearly half a century.

Let's start by meeting at Starbucks, to introduce ourselves over coffee.

Then we'll go over to MOMA, to see the Picasso Sculpture show, a few days before it opens to the general public.  See a link at

http://www.moma.org/visit/calendar/exhibitions/1559

I'm hoping we can more or less synchronize our viewing pace, so that we can see--and share--and comment on--the exhibit. 


Attendees are responsible for paying for any purchases from Starbucks, and for the special $5 guest rate to enter MOMA on my membership pass.  That's right, you will save $20 vs. the normal $25 admission price! 


If something comes up and you can't attend, please change your RSVP status as soon as possible.  Given the small size of this meetup group, no-show's would be a big loss.

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Tarot from A-Z. Special class for newbies and those who know a little Tarot.

Have you bought Tarot books? Gone online to learn Tarot?Spoken to others who then told you what you read was wrong? So, for your efforts all you wound up being was confused?

There's a lot of information out there, but none of it helps a person new to Tarot when everything you read says something else.

What do the cards really mean? Who is right? This class will answer those questions and more. It will answer all your questions and clear up any confusion you have.

We will start with the basics and go on from there.

Learning the Tarot is the same as learning a new language, because Tarot is a language, and like any language you have to learn Tarot's special alphabet. Tarot's special alphabet is made up of symbols. Tarot is a symbolic language. With the symbols you will also learn some of Tarot's correspondences (simple Astrology and some Qabalah (The Tree of Life) as they relate to Tarot).

This class is Tarot taught as it should be taught, because with this knowledge and your intuition (we all have intuition), instead of winding up confused you will be able to read almost any Tarot deck, as well as a regular deck of playing cards, if that is your choice.

So, come and join with others who want to learn Tarot as much as you do. This class will meet twice a month in a convenient, safe Manhattan location.

Price: $20.00 per person

Payment can be made in class.

I look forward to meeting everyone in class.

results.description:
Take the "F" train to Roosevelt Island station. Meet at  at 11:00.  Start walk at 11:15 Through the Cherry Tree walkway to the south part of the Island. 

There will be many of us on this walk so feel free to leave the group and explore by yourselves if you like. We will not take attendance or try to keep the group together if you want to explore on you own.

The walk will continue along the shorefront paths of Roosevelt Island and then through the Monument Park at the southern end of the island. We estimate the length to be about three and one half to four miles altogether. Probably about two hours + or- a bit.

The view of the East side of Manhattan's buildings and skyline is gorgeous. The air is much cleaner than between the buildings of the city and the walk is relaxing. We will visit Southpoint Park and then walk all the way to the North end of the Island to the lighthouse park area. We will end the walk back at the "F" train station where those of us who want, can get lunch at one of the several restaurants nearby

As a bonus, there is the overhead Tram Ride over the East River into Manhattan as a gorgeous skyscraper secenic ride across the river. It only costs one subway fare on your Metrocard and ends between  second and third ave at 59th street.   

We would like to ask you for a donation of one dollar to help offset the cost meet up charges us to run these events

results.description:
We'll start out from an established subway line, the Lexington Avenue line,. The meeting point is  walk East towards the East River and then make our way West and North while enjoying the old architecture on some of these amazing old masterpieces (a school, a church, 2 libraries and several residential buildings). We'll then walk on second avenue to see some of the new structures that are related to the development of the second avenue subway. We will then stop by the MTA Second Avenue Subway Community Information Center for a short presentation. We'll move onto Third Avenue and then onto 86th St. where we'll pass many large modern residential buildings as well as some new large food chains and large electronic stores. Our final destination will be The Central Park Reservoir which is also known as The Jackie Kennedy Onassis Reservoir which was once known as the Croton Reservoir. I will relay the history of Central Park as well as the history of the Old Croton Aqueduct (as this once was an active reservoir for NYC). We will end up on Fifth Avenue where you can enjoy 3 museums which are FREE/pay-a -you - wish on Saturdays.

Please note  the $15 MeetUp Member charge per person for this special tour. Discount price for students and senior citizens is offered at $12. This tour's value is actually $250 (for 10 people) as that is my charge for most of my private tours. Kindly provide me with exact payment at the venue.  Like my other walks, I do not plan  to cancel the walk as this is a multi group event.  Also since I set  a 30 person limit, please cancel your RSVP if you decide your initial plans have changed. 
Please feel free to text or call me at[masked] with any questions.

Thank You, Cindy Ladopoulos-NYCindyTouyrs.com

Hey Everyone,

Let's take a scenic walk across the Brooklyn Bridge starting on the brooklyn side.

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/it/a/a1/Brooklyn_Bridge.JPG

Let's meet at the Volleyball Courts at Pier 6 at 10:00 A.M.

There is a parking garage at Pier 6 for anyone driving. The cost for 8 hours is around $20 depending on what type of car you have. If you would like to inquire about parking please call the garage at,

Quik Park at One Brooklyn Bridge Park (360 Furman Street)
(718) 488-0099.

When we meet up we will walk to Pier 1. It is about 10 Minutes away. There is an entrance to the bridge from there, which we can walk across.

Feel free to look for street parking if you do not want to park in the garage. I will send out an email with my cell number, so we can keep in contact.

See you there :)

http://www.brooklynbridgepark.org/visit

results.description:
There are Seven Factors of Awakening in Buddhism.

•  Mindfulness 

• Investigation 

• Energy 

• Joy

•Tranquility 

• Concentration 

• Equanimity

This week we will take a look at Mindfulness, its meaning and practice.

The brief topic discussion will be followed by a guided meditation and time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. I hope you'll join us.

Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds.
results.name: The Seven Factors of Awakening - Mindfulness

results.description:
PLEASE RSVP RESPONSIBLY.


We were at the Brooklyn Botanical Gardens for the winter, the fall, and spring. Although Labor Day will have already occurred, it's still basically Summer.  So, let's see what's in bloom now!! 

There is free admission to the Brooklyn Botanical Gardens on Saturdays between 10 a.m. and noon. So, while 11 a.m. is rather early, we want to get there for no later than 11 a.m. because if the line gets long and we are shooting for closer to noon, we may get blocked out of the free admission.  


We will meet inside the BBG at the gift shop entrance, rather than wait for everyone to then get in line. This is near the Washington Avenue entrance. You can enter the Gardens at the Eastern Parkway entrance, but then you will have to walk towards the Washington Avenue entrance to get to the gift shop. Here's a map to show you what I mean ... http://www.bbg.org/discover/gardens

Bring your cameras!!
results.how_to_find_us: An email will be sent to attendees prior to the event.
results.name: A stroll through the gardens

results.description:
Howdy Benders!  Hope your week is productive.  Sending out a reminder about our session this Saturday same time same place. As the weather changes, it is the perfect opportunity to drag yourself out of bed and unto your yoga mat. When I first wake up and my bed feels so good I have trouble getting out of bed. But then I remember how stressful by my work week was and how imperative yoga is to detoxing my body and aligning my mind and spirit. We owe it to ourselves to feel great! Start investing in yourself by treating yourself right. I can't tell you how many times I didn't feel like doing yoga but how great I felt afterwards.

Think about how you have an opportunity to do yoga in a community setting, meet like-minded people, and support a local business at the same time!

I would like to continue the yoga and would love to see more benders. Please take advantage of this opportunity because it may not be here for long. See you on Saturday. Namaste.
results.name: Bronx Beer and Bend Yoga

results.description:
This is Section 2 for newbies or those who have only been to one meetup with our group:  Section 1 (previously announced) is for all other members.

This unique experience takes us through some of Brooklyn oldest and least known neighborhoods: 

We'll start with the relatively familiar at  theWilliamsburg Waterfront for an optional group lunch at Smorgasburg and we'll proceed South through the neighborhoods of Wallabout, Vinegar Hill and the Navy Yard where we'll enjoy a one-hour guided tour.  Lots to see en route including the Domino Sugar Factory, the wood frame houses of Wallabout, the hollywood-scale Steiner Studios, abandoned mansions, Williamsburg history and much more!  After the tour the add-on option is to saunter over to nearby Fort Greene Park for their end of Summer Jazz Festival (free), which goes until 7pm.  See the entire itinerary below:

(Optional) 11:15am:  Meet at "Handsome Hank's Fish Hut" inside Smorgasburg along the North 7th Street corridor. You can buy your lunch at Hank's (my preference of course :), or any of the food purveyors (or bring your own) and by 11:45am we'll find a place to to sit together (Probably at Northside Piers - south/to the left of Smorgasburg). Make sure you have my cell phone[masked] to text or call if you can't find us.  Here's a useful link:

http://brooklynflea.com/markets/smorgasburg/  

12:30pm SHARP: The  free walking tour begins at Kent Avenue and North 7th Street. (for new members I will have a sign).  Length of tour is 3.5 - 4 miles.


3:00pm  - One hour guided tour (suggested $5) of the main building area for an over view of The Brooklyn Navy Yard which today hosts and promotes an amazing array of activities including over 300 businesses, arts activities, and the world's largest green roof farm.  The Navy Yard was one of the most active and innovative military shipbuilding facilities in the United States. During the Revolutionary War, the site was the anchorage of the notorious British prison ships, on which an estimated 11,000 American patriots and other prisoners died under horrific conditions.


Commissioned by the U.S. Navy in 1801, the Yard was in continuous operation until 1966, playing a crucial role in American naval, industrial, and cultural history, re-inventing itself time and again in response to the military, economic, technological, and social forces affecting the nation as a whole. At its height during World War II, the Yard’s achievements can be described without exaggeration as heroic.

4:00pm:  Say goodbye or head to Fort Greene Park for the Jazz Festival, which goes until 7pm.  For those heading out transportation guidance will be provided.

http://www.fortgreeneparkjazzfestival.com/
results.how_to_find_us: Read All the Instructions and Description!  L train to Bedford Avenue in Brooklyn.  Wall West into the Park and Smorgasburg at N. 7th Street.
results.name: Touring the Brooklyn Navy Yard/Wallabout/Vinegar Hill & Williamsburg Waterfront

results.description:
Tallman Mountain State Park (Rockland Co, NY). 11:15 am. 6 miles. We will hike through the Park and view the berms and salt marsh and learn its interesting history as a former oil tank farm. Then it’s out the Piermont Pier to follow in the footsteps of the 40,000 US Troops per month who marched to the waiting ships to transport them to the Atlantic Theatre during WWII. We will see many sights as we walk the mile-long Piermont pier halfway across the Hudson! Finally, we will learn of the historic transformation of Piermont, NY from a blue collar factory town to its present day status.


Trails include the Tallman Bike Path and the Long Path. Bring lunch and water. Adverse conditions will alter the route. Don't worry, this will be a moderate paced fun hike. Hiking boots or good sneakers recommended.


We meet in front of 450 Piermont Ave. (building with mural), corner of Tate and Piermont Ave. in Piermont NY. Park down Gair St. in municipal lot off to the right. Do Not park on Piermont Avenue.

Great directions can be found at Turning Point Directions. They will take you just a half block away from our meeting spot. Leader: John P. Jurasek:[masked] (no calls after 10pm) or [masked].

Public transportation from the city is available on the 10:40 AM Rockland Coaches 9A bus from the George Washington Bridge Bus Terminal to meet us in Piermont by 11:17. Tell the driver you are going to Piermont, NY. The bus will drop you off right across from 450 Piermont Ave. (building with mural) on the corner of Tate and Piermont Aves. where we will be waiting. You can take the 9:15 Bus from Port Authority Bus Terminal to arrive in Piermont at 10:17 but you will be an hour early. There are shops in town to pass the time.

Please note the many web links in the write-up for valuable additional information.

Steady rain or serious threat of thunderstorms will modify or cancel hike.
results.how_to_find_us: We meet in front of 450 Piermont Ave. (building with mural), corner of Tate and Piermont Ave. in Piermont NY.
results.name: Tallman Mountain State Park and Piermont Pier Hike

results.description:
Bike Brooklyn

Here's the plan:

We'll be gathering at Get Up & Ride located at 330 S 3rd Street in Williamsburg.  If you have a bike you can meet us there at 11:30 am.  If you will be renting, please arrive early enough to have your bike and ready to go at 11:30.  You may want to reserve in advance to insure you'll get a bike.  You can do this from their website:  http://www.getupandride.com/  You may get from other places if you choose, but I found this to be the most accommodating and a good meeting spot.  


A little about the Bike Rental:

Cost:  $35/day (incl bike, helmet, & lock)

These are lighter road bikes in black/brown so you don't look like a tourist on a Citibike.  I do NOT recommend Citibike for this ride as our time/route will not be conducive to docking every 45 min.  

The Route:  

From the bike rental at 330 S 3rd, we'll make our way over to the Williamsburg waterfront to Kent Ave.  From there we'll be taking Flushing Ave passing the Brooklyn Navy Yard through Clinton Hill.  From there we'll maintain our route along the waterfront past Brooklyn Bridge Park to Columbia Street.  Columbia St will take us through Carroll Gardens down to one of our stops at Louis Valentino Junior Park.  This is a perfect spot for view/pictures of the Statue of Liberty.  From there we'll head over to Prospect Park where we'll stop at a local cafe for a coffee or a snack and some socializing.  From Prospect Park we'll head back to the bike rental place where we started.  The whole trip  is about 14 miles.  

I may adjust the route a bit between now and then, but this will be our general loop.  


RSVP:  Open!

Note, biking in New York City can be dangerous!  You are responsible for your own safety.  It's recommended that you familiarize yourself with all biking rules and regulations prior to participating in this event.  By participating in this event you assume your own risk and agree to hold harmless the organizers and/or leaders of this group in the event of any loss or injury.
